This book describes how the Army's involvement in the Pacific began in 1898 with and expedition to seize Manilla from Spain. Continues to World War II, Korea, and Vietnam. This broad historical perspective reveals some enduring lessons; vast distances and diversity of terrain and weather, the necessity for joint and multinational operations, and the need for a versatile, adaptive, and agile force.

About the Author
James C. McNaughton is chief of the Contemporary Studies Branch, Histories Division, U.S. Army Center of Military History. He previously served as the command historian for several Army and Joint commands, including the U.S. Army, Pacific. He received a B.A. degree from Middlebury College, Vermont, and M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in history from Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland. He has served as an officer in the Active Army, National Guard, and Army Reserve, and as an Army civilian. He is the author of Nisei Linguists: Japanese Americans in the Military Intelligence Service during World War II (2006).
